properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 141 Sanders Circle East Montpelier VTCombination horse and sheep barn with 60\' by 36\' hay loft over. Center alley asphalt. Heated tack room with hot water available as is electricity. Frost free hydrant in and just outside barn. Single story shed attached for farm equipment.

properties.name: 2304 Main Street
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 2304 Main Street Isle La Motte VT18th Century Scottish stone barn design Stone Mason: James Ritchie (ca. 1830) Owner (1830): Ira Hill Restoration architect (2008): Glenn Bydwell Restoration framer (2008): Jan Lewandoski Retoration stonemason (2008): Mark Mendel, Monterey Masonry Resotration carpenter (2008): Jeff Fellinger

properties.name: 3 Irish Settlement Road #1
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 13" +/- square tie beams Log rafters, some with bark remaining Sliding garage door added to north gable end Located on Pleasant Valley Rd across from Irish Settlement Road (gable end faces road) 3 animal stalls South bay floor collapsed within last year Built into bank with lower level access at south gable end Structural failure was related to foundation. Roof structure in good/fair condition. Floor framing, sills and foundation failing. Believe barn built at same time as house Builder built at least one other house on Beartown Road in Underhill Center Builder operated a sawmill on Irish Settlement Road Builder died in the Civil War Original farm included property on both sides of Pleasant Valley Road and Irish Settlement Road (including the current Underhill Central School property) Story: person was used to bringing carriage into barn and saying,"Whoa!" and the horses would stop. When first entered barn with Model T Ford, said,"Whoa!", hopped out and auto drove out the opposite door. Barn in process of being dismantled. Salvageable timbers will be reused by a timber frame contractor.

properties.name: 3 Irish Settlement Road #2
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus Concrete slab floor Collapsed, being removed from site

properties.name: 320 Browns Trace
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus The barn was built ion 1820. It is 28x35 feet, on a stone foundation. It is built into a slight hill, allowing for a chicken coop under about 1/3 of the structure. The first floor has a wide open space with two animal stalls in the back. The second story is reached by a narrow staircase and has a wide door in the front, apparently to get hay upstairs. There\'s also an open place for tossing hay down to the first floor. The shape of the barn looks like a typical "English Barn", except the double door s are in the narrow end rather than the long side. Town records show that a "spinster" lived here in the mid-1800\'s and had a market garden. The house and barn were also owned by someone who built the cabinets for Seth Thomas clocks. There were several chunks of assorted hardwoods upstairs in the barn when I moved here.

properties.name: 44 Kylies Way
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 44 Kylies Way, Colchester, VT 054461850\'s English barn.

properties.name: 466 elm Street, Montpelier, VT

properties.name: 51 North Street
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus This barn was added onto the east side of an existing gable end barn ( \' x \') that is no longer standing. It was built-out perpendicular to the north-south ridge of the existing barn. The first floor was designed to be clear span with two king post trusses that span 30 ft (creating 3 bays) running east-west, front wall to back wall. The second floor is framed into the bottom chord, and the kingpost supports a beam (running north-south) that the roof is framed into. The north and west exterior walls are parapet walls around a shed type roof with a slope of 1-2 on 12. A coachman reportedly lived in the barn during the early 1900\'s when the house was owned by a Doctor. This is evidenced by markings that there was a \' x \' room in the south east corner. The exterior walls in this area are filled with sawdust, there is an inactive chimney in this corner of the barn, and markings where there was an electric light in the center of this room and a wall switch. Foundation/Cellar: The barn has full cellar - possibly a manure pit? First Floor: Electrical wiring was installed within the framing spaces before interior finishes were applied indicating that there was electricity available when it was constructed, about 1900. The interior walls and ceiling on the first floor were finished with 6" beaded board, painted a dull green. The windows casings are the same beaded board. There are three grain chutes in the southwest corner from the second floor.

properties.name: Dr. Jones Property
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus This village barn is attached to the main house with an ell; it was shown on both the 1858 and 1875 village maps; in the early 1900\'s it was the home of Dr. S A Jones. Today the home is a day care center; the attached barn is still in excellent condition and well maintained.

properties.name: Eddy-Babcock Barn
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 1123 Bayley-Hazen Road East Hardwick VT 05836The Eddy-Babcock farm, on the Bayley-Hazen Military Road, was first settled in the early 1810s - one of the earliest in Walden. Capt. Edmund Eddy purchased the farm in 1819 and three generations of the Eddy family farmed this land until 1915 when the farm was purchased by Clyde Babcock. The farm reached its zenith under Clyde Babcock who owned the farm until 1953 at which time the farmstead consisted of the following structures: farmhouse with ell, sugar house, carriage shop, schoolhouse, horse barn, exterior silo, chicken coop, well house, equipment shed and ice house in addition to the main barn, cow barn and milkhouse mentioned above. Of these, only the farmhouse and ell (built ca. 1830s), the main barn, the cow barn and the milkhouse are extant.

properties.name: Folsom Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus This barn is attached with an ell to a main house, which was called the Sheffield House and later the Folsom Hotel, owned by Noah Folsom. The stagecoach stopped here at the four corners of Sheffield Village from 1850 through 1880

properties.name: Franks Dairy Farm
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus First built in 1977 with1991 additions.Interesting remnant of the old out house on the back of the farm house. Original late bank barn was struck by lightening (road named after the extensive lightening in the area) and burned. Continuing in the agricultural theme of the area; heavy dairy community.

properties.name: Frost Home
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 3215 VT Route 122, Sheffield VTThis is a carriage barn attached to an ell, attached to the main house. It was shown on the Beers 1858 map as the home of the village doctor. One can imagine the doctor hitching up his horse and buggy to spend the day visiting patients around the Sheffield hillside farms. This property is in fine condition, wonderfully preserved.

properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus First built behind the house in 1790 then moved in 1800s. Original owner Walter Slayton of Mass. Family owned (Martin/Nunn) for 105 years. Remaining family refuses to demolish the barn. One of the oldest barns in Vermont, begining of the agricultural theme of dairy farming in this county.

properties.name: Mead-Fay Farm
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 133 River Road Underhill VT 05489Only concrete foundation of silo remains, silo has been removed. Shed on rear gable - "honey wagon" for loading manure into wagon (wagon backs in) "Mead-Fay Farm 1806" written on front gable. Calendar from 1952 still hanging in front room. Counter weighted hay doors. Approx 4 foot square wooden air duct at center of hay floor (beneath upper ridge, running length of barn). Large fan towards front gable. Separate equipment barn nearby. 24 stalls (12 each side) just removed in Jan 2008. Mead family owned farm for 200 years (1806 - 2006). Adjacent house dates from 1830\'s. Old barn on other side of River Road has been gone for years.

properties.name: Mead-Fay Farm 1
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 131 River Road Underhill VTOnly concrete foundation of silo remains, silo has been removed. Shed on rear gable - "honey wagon" for loading manure into wagon (wagon backs in) "Mead-Fay Farm 1806" written on front gable. Calendar from 1952 still hanging in front room. Counter weighted hay doors. Approx 4 foot square wooden air duct at center of hay floor (beneath upper ridge, running length of barn). Large fan towards front gable. Separate equipment barn nearby. 24 stalls (12 each side) just removed in Jan 2008. Mead family owned farm for 200 years (1806 - 2006). Adjacent house dates from 1830\'s. Old barn on other side of River Road has been gone for years.

properties.name: Morris Barn
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 115 Main Street Poultney VT"This barn was part of the property of a merchant, Isaac Leffingwell, who purchased the house and barn in 1836 or 1837. We do not have information as to who was the original owner nor when the barn was built. The original house was demolished in 1958 to enable construction of the Poultney Post Office. Isaac Leffingwell was a merchant and constructed a store building next to his house in 1840 which stands today in front of the barn." "The barn dimensions are 34\' x 24\'. It is divided in the middle by a wagon bay with two stables to the left (east) and with storage space and an out-house to the right. Above the stables and the storage space are hay mows. The construction is post and beam with timber about 10 to 12 inches square. The roof rafters are split tree trunks about 6 to 8 inches wide and sawn rafters about 4 inches wide have been added i later years we presume to support the slate roof. Some roof shingles can be seen from inside beneath the slate, and therefore we believe the slate roof is not original to the barn since slate quarrying was not begun in the area until around 1840. The floor of the barn is made of wood planks about 12 to 15 inches wide and about four inches thick, As shown in the photos, there are large double doors for access to the wagon bay area, a four foot wide door, and a 26" door to the out-house. At the rear in the middle is a door ad windows are located to either side."

properties.name: Ray Berry Farm
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 1965 Berry Hill Road Sheffield VTsmall ell on gable end is sawdust bin; barn is three stories; manure drops to basement level; horses stalled in basement level; middle level is the dairy, where cows are milked; top level is for hay storage. This property also has a working sawmill. This barn is an historic example of 19th century arrangements; cows are still stanchioned on the middle level, with original wooden stanchions; historic small milking arrangement and hand carved feed troughs. In 1929 the second floor was renovated with concrete floors. The separate milk house was added on. The property has an original 1898 sugarhouse with original equpment; wooden sap tank, wooden gathering tank for horse driven sled; structures contains hewn rafters.

properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus The wood silo is attached to the main barn by a short shed. There is an exterior covered ladder and an exterior metal ladder. This early barn was at one time attached to the home with an ell. Research and early photographs show that the silo was built much later than the barn; it is round with iron rings around vertical barn board. The roof is double gabled with board and wood shingles and a ventilator top.

properties.name: Wellsmere
properties.description: Posted by Vtbarncensus 199 VT Route 30 Wells VTIn 1960 23 farms shipped milk out of Wells. Today there are none. Oldest section of barn has hand-hewn post and beam- hay barn held two hay dryers which are fans blowing-rolls of hay were placed cutend down on slotted floors.- there were 8 bents in the 3 sections. Mrs. Hyck owned Wellsmere during the Depression. she created jobs for locals. they built stone walls around her farm as well as building the town library next to the farm house (Wells Historical Society has photo) It\'s cement slab still exists. the third left section of the barn is the hefer barn. It contains some small pens. A corn chopper was placed outside after strings were pulled off bundles of corn. the corn was shot up into the right or left interior silos.
